title: Numerical Expressions
description: Master the rules for writing numbers in Canadian style

questions.stem: Which sentence correctly follows the basic number rule?

options.label: We ordered 9 computers and twelve desks.
We ordered nine computers and 12 desks.
We ordered nine computers and twelve desks.
We ordered 9 computers and 12 desks.

questions.rationale: Numbers one through nine are typically spelled out, while 10 and above use numerals. However, be consistent within a sentence.

questions.stem: Complete using the correct number format:
questions.text: The meeting lasted ____ hours and included ____ participants.
questions.hint: Consider the basic rule for numbers one through nine versus 10 and above.
questions.rationale: Numbers one through nine are spelled out, numbers 10 and above use numerals.

questions.text: The report shows that 5 departments spent more than twelve thousand dollars.
questions.rationale: Numbers one through nine should be spelled out in regular text.

questions.stem: Which sentence correctly handles a number at the beginning?

options.label: 25 people attended the meeting.
Twenty-five people attended the meeting.
A total of 25 people attended the meeting.
Both B and C are correct

questions.rationale: Numbers beginning a sentence should be spelled out, or the sentence should be rewritten to avoid starting with a number.

questions.stem: Arrange these sentence openings from most to least preferred:
questions.instructions: Order by preference in Canadian style:
questions.rationale: Spelled-out numbers are most preferred, followed by rewording to avoid starting with numerals.

questions.text: The budget allocation was $____ for equipment and $____ for training.
questions.hint: Use numerals for all monetary amounts regardless of the basic rule.
questions.rationale: Monetary amounts always use numerals, with commas for thousands.

options.label: The room measures 5 metres by 3 metres.
The room measures five metres by three metres.
The room measures 5 m by 3 m.
Both A and C are correct

questions.rationale: Measurements use numerals regardless of the basic number rule. Both full words and abbreviations are acceptable.

questions.stem: Find the error in this monetary expression:
questions.text: The cost increased from $five hundred to $1,200 last year.
questions.rationale: All monetary amounts should use numerals: $500.

questions.stem: Match each date format with its appropriate context:
questions.rationale: Different date formats serve different purposes and contexts.

questions.text: The meeting starts at ____ and ends at ____.
questions.hint: Use standard time format with periods in a.m./p.m.
questions.rationale: Time uses numerals with lowercase a.m./p.m. including periods.

options.label: The success rate was 85%.
The success rate was eighty-five percent.
The success rate was 85 percent.
Both A and C are correct

questions.rationale: Percentages use numerals and can be written with % symbol or 'percent' spelled out.

questions.stem: Arrange these statistical expressions in order of formality:
questions.rationale: Spelled-out 'percent' is most formal, followed by % symbol, then approximations.

questions.stem: Find the error in this statistical statement:
questions.text: Survey results show that 8% prefer coffee while thirty-two percent prefer tea.
questions.rationale: Be consistent within a document - use either numerals or spelled-out numbers for all percentages.

questions.text: Please deliver to ____ Main Street, Apartment ____.
questions.rationale: Street addresses, apartment numbers, and postal information use numerals.

questions.stem: Which age expression follows Canadian style?

options.label: She is 25 years old.
She is twenty-five years old.
She is 25-years-old.
She is in her twenties.

questions.rationale: Specific ages use numerals, while general age ranges can be spelled out.
